skill.name: payload
skill.description: Use when working with Payload CMS projects (payload.config.ts, collections, fields, hooks, access control, Payload API). Use when debugging validation errors, security issues, relationship queries, transactions, or hook behavior.
skill.summary: Use when working with Payload CMS projects (payload.config.ts, collections, fields, hooks, access co...
skill.author: payloadcms

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill containing only markdown reference files with TypeScript code examples for Payload CMS. No executable code exists. All 1016 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES: the analyzer incorrectly flagged JavaScript template literals (backticks) as Ruby shell execution, standard configuration patterns as credential access, and documentation URLs as network calls.

content.value_statement: Creating backend APIs and admin panels with Payload CMS requires understanding collections, fields, hooks, and access control patterns. This skill provides comprehensive documentation and code examples for building TypeScript-first CMS applications with Next.js integration.
actual_capabilities: Generate collection configurations with auth, uploads, and versioning
Create field types including relationships, arrays, blocks, and rich text
Implement access control with role-based permissions and row-level security
Build custom hooks for data validation, transformations, and side effects
Query data using Local API, REST endpoints, and GraphQL
Develop plugins that extend Payload CMS functionality
limitations: Does not execute code or modify live Payload CMS instances
Does not provide direct database access or migrations
Does not install or configure Payload CMS projects
Limited to documentation and pattern guidance only

use_cases.title: Build CMS backends
use_cases.description: Create headless CMS backends with collections, fields, and authentication using TypeScript patterns.

use_cases.title: Integrate with Next.js
use_cases.description: Connect Payload CMS with Next.js applications using Local API and revalidation patterns.

use_cases.title: Extend Payload CMS
use_cases.description: Create plugins that add collections, fields, hooks, and admin components to Payload projects.

prompt_templates.title: Basic collection setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to create a Payload CMS collection with text fields, relationship fields, and access control for authenticated users.

prompt_templates.title: Custom hooks
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I create beforeChange and afterChange hooks in Payload CMS to auto-generate slugs and send notifications?

prompt_templates.title: Access control
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to implement row-level access control in Payload CMS so users can only see their own documents.

prompt_templates.title: Plugin development
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I create a Payload CMS plugin that adds SEO fields to specified collections?

output_examples.input: Create a Payload CMS collection for blog posts with title, content, author relationship, and draft publishing.
output: Collection config with slug, fields array, and timestamps
Text field for title with required and index
RichText field for content using lexical editor
Relationship field linking to users collection
Select field for status with draft/published options
Access control: public read for published, authenticated read for all
Versions config with drafts enabled for preview workflow

output_examples.input: Set up access control so users can only edit their own documents
output: Collection-level access control function with user roles check
Row-level where clause filtering by author ID
Admin role exception returning true for full access
Update and delete operations restricted to document owner
Read access for published content without authentication

output_examples.input: Create a beforeChange hook to auto-generate URL slugs from title
output: Hook function receiving data and operation parameters
Slug generation logic only on create operation
Slugify function for URL-safe string conversion
Return modified data object for persistence

best_practices: Use TypeScript types from payload package for type-safe configurations
Pass req parameter to nested operations in hooks for transaction safety
Set overrideAccess false when operating on behalf of authenticated users
Use context object to share data between hooks and prevent infinite loops
anti_patterns: Passing user to Local API without setting overrideAccess false (bypasses security)
Missing req parameter in nested operations within hooks (breaks atomicity)
Not using context to prevent recursive hook calls (causes infinite loops)
Storing secrets or credentials in field configurations or client-side code

faq.question: What databases does Payload CMS support?
faq.answer: Payload supports MongoDB with mongoose adapter, PostgreSQL with postgres adapter, and SQLite with sqlite adapter. All support transactions when properly configured.

faq.question: How do I query relationships efficiently?
faq.answer: Use the depth parameter to control relationship population. Set maxDepth on relationship fields to prevent over-fetching. Use select parameter to limit returned fields.

faq.question: Can I use this skill with Next.js App Router?
faq.answer: Yes. Use getPayload from payload package in Server Components. Call revalidatePath in afterChange hooks to trigger ISR when content changes.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill contains only documentation patterns. It does not access your database, execute code on your system, or transmit any data externally.

faq.question: Why does Local API bypass access control?
faq.answer: Local API assumes server-side trust by default. Set overrideAccess false when passing a user to enforce their permissions. This prevents unintended privilege escalation.

faq.question: How does this compare to other CMS skills?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on Payload CMS specifically, providing comprehensive reference for its TypeScript-first architecture. Other CMS skills cover different platforms with different patterns.
